title: Improve guideline for image alt text
body:
After digging into this rule a little more with @evcohen, I believe that
it is okay for images to have an empty string for alt text. I expect the
next release of the linter rule to allow for this as well.

More context:

  https://github.com/evcohen/eslint-plugin-jsx-a11y/issues/6

title: Updated eslint rule and small fix for consistency
body:
1. Add "eslint:" to 7.6 in README for consistency.
2. Update the ESLint rule for 18.3 in README. In ESLint v2.0, "keyword-spacing" has replaced "space-before-keywords" and "space-after-keywords". See links below:
   -http://eslint.org/docs/rules/space-after-keywords.html
   -http://eslint.org/docs/rules/space-before-keywords.html

title: Clash between max-len and prefer-template
body: This errors because of [max-len](http://eslint.org/docs/rules/max-len): ``` js let report = `${headline}` ``` ...but if I try to break it up over multiple lines by separating it into strings and concatenating with `+`, it errors because of [prefer-template](http://eslint.org/docs/rules/prefer-template). What am I supposed to do in this situation?

title: Add some accessibility rules to the React style guide
body:
I think there is a good opportunity to improve accessibility guidelines in this style guide. This PR takes the first steps in that direction by enabling a handful of rules from eslint-plugin-jsx-a11y and adding some text about these rules.

There are more rules from this plugin that I would like to enable, but I'm going to leave that for another time.

While I was at it, I switched the syntax highlighting on the codeblocks in the react style guide to highlight JSX better.

title: React style guide should give guidance on conditionals in JSX
body: I have come across a code base which references this style guide and uses `&&` instead of ternaries in JSX. After discussing in gitter with @megapctr, this practice should be avoided and a ternary should be used instead.

title: Adding The Nerdery to the "In the Wild" section
body: If ya'll could add The Nerdery to list of organizations, that would be peachy keen! Loving the style guide!

title: Add KickorStick to 'In the Wild'
Broken link to Classes and constructors
Removed trailing whitespace
Fixed missing eslint heading
CHORE - Remove Trailing Spaces
body: Remove Trailing Spaces

title: Option to remove eslint react plugin
body: We enjoy the airbnb eslint config/rules for our ES6 JS code, but we don't use react. Is there a way an option to remove the dependency on the react plugin?

title: Type in #iterators--nope
Add Chartboost to 'In the Wild'
body: Chartboost uses the AirBnB style guide.

title: react/jsx-no-bind: why refs and arrow functions are allowed?
body: In the `3.x.x` this rule was turned on. Reasoning is clear and makes a perfect sense. But [this commit](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/issues/784) doesn't make sense to me. Why refs and arrow functions are allowed, while bind is not? New arrow functions are being created on each re-render and they `!==` to each other, so what's the point of this rule with this change?

title: Add missing description for 7.2
Linting not working in a non-react project
body:
Just tried using this library on a non react project, and I got the following error:

```
$ eslint index.js                                                                                                                                                    

Oops! Something went wrong! :(

ESLint couldn't find the plugin "eslint-plugin-react". This can happen for a couple different reasons:

1. If ESLint is installed globally, then make sure eslint-plugin-react is also installed globally. A globally-installed ESLint cannot find a locally-installed plugin.

2. If ESLint is installed locally, then it's likely that the plugin isn't installed correctly. Try reinstalling by running the following:

    npm i eslint-plugin-react@latest --save-dev

If you still can't figure out the problem, please stop by https://gitter.im/eslint/eslint to chat with the team.
```

This is despite the fact that my `.eslintrc` reads: `"extends": "airbnb/base"`. In my other react related projects, however, the library works like charm.

Library was installed using: `npm install --save-dev eslint-config-airbnb eslint`

Thanks!

PS: Since react projects are a subset of all javascript projects, I think that the default `"extends": "airbnb"` should lint the general javascript project, and maybe have `"extends": "airbnb/react"` support the subset of projects that use react.

title: upgrade eslint to v2.5.3; add new rules
body: I did not yet add http://eslint.org/docs/rules/max-statements-per-line because I'm not convinced it's properly implemented.

title: About no-nested-ternary
body:
I sometimes use the following syntax that I find elegant and useful.
What do you think about it? And What do you suggest to replace it?

```js
var foo =
  condition1 ? a :
  condition2 ? b :
  condition3 ? c :
  d;
```

title: Add SysGarage to list of organizations
body: I accidentally dropped the branch and automatically closed previous pull request #795

title: Add SysGarage to list of organizations
7.1 says function expressions are always unnamed, but this changed in ES6
body:
[7.1](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript#functions--declarations) contains this statement:

> Function declarations are named, so they're easier to identify in call stacks.

Anonymous function expressions assigned to a binding are _also_ named, per [ES6 semantics (1.e.iii).](http://www.ecma-international.org/ecma-262/6.0/#sec-assignment-operators-runtime-semantics-evaluation) That is, the "bad" example `const foo = function () { };` is the same as `const foo = function foo() { };`, which is equivalent to the "good" example `function foo() { }` in that respect.

Should the statement be qualified that it's only a distinction for ES5 and below ?

title: Fix "object destructuring for multiple return values" example
body: ... to use the same destructured properties in the good and bad code.

title: `no-confusing-arrow` rule is already fixed in ESLint 2.4.0
body: https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/issues/752 looks like fixed, right? I think we can enable it back.

title: Fix react/prefer-stateless-function link in eslint changelog
body: Pretty straight forward as the headline already describes this PR.

title: Add space to function signature
body: At 7.11 you say that function signatures should have spacing, yet there's no space in this function signature. This is confusing.

title: object spread
Add ascribe's styleguide to the list
body:
Thank you very much for creating this styleguide!
Ascribe :heart: you.

title: Stateless example seems wrong?
body:
I noticed in the React guide it says to use regular functions because of the Function.name thing.

However, I noticed that when using Babel, it seems to output a function with the same name as the variable. So therefore wouldn't it in fact have a Function.name?

![](http://d.pr/i/1cvPJ+)

See what I mean?

![](http://d.pr/i/1jESi+)

Unless I missed something... :)

@ljharb I noticed you committed this bit. Thoughts?
